title: Ticket #413: dagman has linear search when parsing dag
description:
So, I had performed a test to see if dagman could handle a one million node dag. The structure of the dag is one parent, 1 million children, then one end node. It turns out it took 2 hrs and 30 minutes to parse! This was because the parent/waiting/child structures for each node were linked lists. When a new node was added as a child to the original parent node, a linear search happened to determine if it had already been added. If not, it was added. So, this became an n^2 algorithm.

I replaced the SimpleList structure with an STL set instead. This sped it up to 2 minutes and 30 seconds for the parse. However, it broke the DFSVisit code which was written before the Priority stuff went in. So, once I fix that latter, and write some tests, I'll check it in. Hopefully, it'll build everywhere since it uses the STL. :)
remarks:
2009-Apr-28 20:25:31 by psilord:
Kent wrote a test for the dfs ordering code, and I was mistaken, it is not broken. Luckily, now we have a test for it. :) So, once I fix a compiler error under creepy windows for the stl I want to do. I'll check it in.

2009-Apr-28 21:36:30 by psilord:
Hrm, failed build under windows. I guess my iterators had to be const due to some member functions being const and the set being a member variable. I wish gcc would have complained about this earlier instead of silently accepting it.

2009-Apr-30 10:19:27 by psilord:
This code is ready for review and has passed NMI to my satisfaction.

2009-Apr-30 14:58:44 by psilord:
Code review is finished, suggested changes (very small) made.

2009-Apr-30 16:27:52 by psilord:
The branch V7_3-dagspeed-branch which contained this code was squashed into the master branch. This is because this feature really looked like a "single commit" type feature wrt master branch--and in case of reversion, it is far easier to do it like this in this specific case.

The V7_3-dagspeed-branch should be abandoned now.
